person.note: In Palmyrene script, see Introduction 2.8.2. For this form see vol. 1, Alexander (20) G/M, pp. 258, 260, n. 4.
The inscription was found in a Jewish tomb in Jerusalem, see Introduction 6.4.1. This person is recorded in vol. 1 (Alexander [20]), p. 258, but not included in the statistics.

All the inscriptions in this tomb were identified as Palmyrene, because some of them were written in the Palmyrene script and many had Latin names, which were not typical at the time in Jerusalem, but seem to have been more so in Palmyra, see e.g. the list of Palmyrene soldiers in Welles et al. Dura-Europos (1959) 100, 101.
See vol. 1, Introduction 7.6.1, p. 52.
In Palmyrene script, see Introduction 2.8.2. On transliterations from Greek see Introduction 2.2.1. For the א suffix see vol. 1, Introduction 2.4.2.8, p. 26.
It may be suggested that the inscription is Jewish because of his father’s name, but see Introduction 6.5.3.1.
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date assumed, see Introduction 8.4.3.
Both suffixes are correct, but this form is not recorded in WGE. On such alternative suffixes see vol. 3, Introduction 2.3.3.7.2, pp. 16-7.
This form is also found in mss of this text. I believe it is influenced by the NT Barnabas, see vol. 1, Nabas (1) G-S/M, p. 439.
This text is a description of a Christian-Jewish dispute.
In this religious dispute he belongs to the Jewish delegation.
The text is fictitious, and see next note.

This is a fictitious account of a religious dispute between Jews and Christians in the Sasanian court, before a fictitious Sasanian king (Arrinatus). It could have taken place in any of these centuries, see Introduction 8.1.

state.note: Stamp seal on jar, synagogue Dura-Europos, Welles

person.note: Found in the synagogue, see Introduction 6.3.2. This was the name of the manufacturer who supplied the synagogue with produce stored in this jar, but he need not himself have been Jewish, see Introduction 6.3.2.
The stamp-seal is dated, see Introduction 8.4.1.
All three forms are recorded on the bowl. On the transliteration of η with י see Introduction 2.2.1.3. On the א suffix see vol. 1, Introduction 2.4.2.1, p. 25.

The authors of the Aramaic incantation bowls were Jewish, but there is no reason to suppose that all their clients were, see Introduction 6.7. However, the parallel between the name of this man’s mother-in-law andאמא שלום of rabbinic literature (see vol. 1, Salome [7] B/F, p. 249) suggests that this client was Jewish, see Introduction 6.5.
On the dating of the Aramaic incantation bowls see Introduction 8.5.
The graffito was found in a synagogue, and was presumably (but not necessarily) executed by a Jew, see Introduction 6.3.2.
Date suggested by editor.

The inscription is bilingual – Hebrew and Greek. So in the Greek. The editor reconstructed the name based on the Hebrew, see Introduction 2.1. The interchange of ο and α is probably a scribal error, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.8.4, p. 20.

The inscription is bilingual – Hebrew and Greek. So in the Hebrew. The fall of the ר is probably a scribal error, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.8.2, p. 20. On the ין suffix see vol. 1, Introduction 2.4.3.2, p. 27.
The inscription is partly in Jewish characters, see Introduction 6.2. The persons mentioned in it are described as ̓Ιουδέων (of the Jews), see Introduction 6.1. And see also Introduction 6.4.3.
Date suggested by the editor, see Introduction 8.4.2.3.
Described in the text as ̓Ιουδαῖον τὸ γένος (Jewish by descent), see Introduction 6.1.
His name in Greek means “giant.” This could refer to his dimensions rather than be viewed as a name.
See vol. 1, Introduction 7.2, p. 51.

The reading is according to C: H. Gordon, “Aramaic Magical Bowls in the Istanbul and Baghdad Museums,” Archiv Orientální 6 (1934), 322. Isbell has גריגני. The transliteration is straightforward, but lacks a case suffix, see Introduction 2.2.1.1.

The authors of the Aramaic incantation bowls were Jewish, but there is no reason to suppose that all their clients were, see Introduction 6.7. In this case, however, the name of his sister (Mariam [3]) may suggest that he was, but see Introduction 6.5.4.1.
On the dating of the Aramaic incantation bowls see Introduction 8.5.
Described in the text as ̓Ιουδαῖος (Jew), see Introduction 6.1.
The text is fictitious, and see next note.

This is a fictitious account of a religious dispute between Jews and Christians in the Sasanian court, before a fictitious Sasanian king (Arrinatus). It could have taken place in any of these centuries, see Introduction 8.1.

In Palmyrene script, see Introduction 2.8.2. The inscription is bilingual, Greek and Palmyrene. So in the Palmyrene script, see Introduction 2.8.2. It is amended according to the Greek. For the ן suffix see vol. 1, Introduction 2.4.3.3, p. 27.
The inscription is bilingual, Greek and Palmyrene. So in the Greek script. It is amended according to the Palmyrene, see Introduction 2.1.
The inscriptions were found in a Jewish cemetery in Palestine, see Introduction 6.4.2.
This is the year in which Beth Sheʿarim was destroyed, see Introduction 8.4.2.1.
The inscription was found in a Jewish tomb in Jerusalem, see Introduction 6.4.1. This person is recorded in vol. 1 (Epictetus [1]), p. 277, but not included in the statistics.

All the inscriptions in this tomb were identified as Palmyrene, because some of them were written in the Palmyrene script and many had Latin names, which were not typical at the time in Jerusalem, but seem to have been more so in Palmyra, see e.g. the list of Palmyrene soldiers in Welles et al. Dura-Europos (1959) 100, 101.
See vol. 1, Introduction 7.6.1, p. 52.

state.note: Inscription on jar, synagogue Dura-Europos, Welles

person.note: The jar was found in the synagogue, see Introduction 6.3.2. This was the name of the manufacturer who supplied the synagogue with the produce stored in this jar, but he need not himself have been Jewish, see Introduction 6.3.2.
The inscription may be dated to this year, see Introduction 8.4.1.

state.note: Stamp seal on jar, Dura-Europos, du Mesnil

person.note: On this sort of abbreviation see vol. 3, Introduction 2.3.1, p. 13.

This jar with the stamp on it was found in the synagogue, see Introduction 6.3. It is accompanied with what looks like the stamp of a palm frond. This suggests that the jar owner may have been Jewish, but see Introduction 6.3.2.
This is the date on which the synagogue was incorporated into the earthworks of the city fortification and destroyed, see Introduction 8.4.2.2.
The root letters in the name agree. On the transliteration of η with י see Introduction 2.2.1.3. On the ה suffix see vol. 1, Introduction 2.4.2.8, p. 26.
The script and Aramaic of the document have been identified by the editor, in comparison with other material, as Jewish, see Introduction 6.2.
The papyrus is dated, see Introduction 8.4.1.
Jewishness indicated by father’s name, see Introduction 6.5.4.1. And see also Introduction 6.4.3.
The inscription is dated, see Introduction 8.4.1.

In Syriac Script (הוסיך), see Introduction 2.8.1. On the interchange of vowel-consonant order as a scribal error see vol. 3, Introduction 2.8.3, p. 20; or as alternative dialect see Introduction 2.3.5.1. On the fall of the suffix see Introduction 2.2.1.1.
The events in which he is mentioned take place in the house of the Bishop of Tella.
Described in the text as ܝܗܘܕܝܐ (Jew), see Introduction 6.1.
The synod at Ephesus took place in this year.
This is the suggested reading of the editor, see Introduction 2.1.
The inscription was found in a Jewish tomb in Jerusalem, see Introduction 6.4.1. This person is recorded in vol. 1 (Theodorus [7]), p. 286, but not included in the statistics.

All the inscriptions in this tomb were identified as Palmyrene, because some of them were written in the Palmyrene script and many had Latin names, which were not typical at the time in Jerusalem, but seem to have been more so in Palmyra, see e.g. the list of Palmyrene soldiers in Welles et al. Dura-Europos (1959) 100, 101.
See vol. 1, Introduction 7.6.1, p. 52.

In the Palmyrene script, see Introduction 2.8.2. On this transliteration of the name see vol. 1, Theodorus G/M, p. 287, n. 22. On the transliteration of σ with ש see vol. 1, Introduction 2.2.5, pp. 20-1. On the abbreviated suffix see Introduction 2.2.1.2.
The inscriptions were found in a Jewish cemetery in Palestine, see Introduction 6.4.2.
This is the year in which Beit Sheʿarim was destroyed, see Introduction 8.4.2.1.
This is a straightforward transliteration, see Introduction 2.2.1.
The inscription is in Jewish characters, see Introduction 6.2. And see also Introduction 6.4.3.

Date suggested by the editor, see Introduction 8.4.2.3. For doubts about it see D. Shapira, “Gleanings on Jews of Greater Iran under the Sasanians according to the Oldest Armenian and Georgian Texts,” Iran and the Caucasus 12 (2008-9) 7-10.
Reading suggested by the editor, see Introduction 2.1.

The inscription is accompanied by the GreekΕἱς Θεὸς̔ βοαθο͂ν(one God the protector). On such inscriptions see Introduction 6.9. Bowersock claims the inscription should be interpreted as Jewish because of the mention of theἅγιος τόπος(holy place) in the inscription, which he understands as reserved for Jewish synagogues, but on this see vol. 3, Introduction 6.4.1.2.4 p. 42.
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date assumed, see Introduction 8.4.3.
The inscription was found in a Jewish tomb in Jerusalem, see Introduction 6.4.1.

All the inscriptions in this tomb were identified as Palmyrene, because some of them were written in the Palmyrene script and many had Latin names, which were not typical at the time in Jerusalem, but seem to have been more so in Palmyra, see e.g. the list of Palmyrene soldiers in Welles et al. Dura-Europos (1959) 100, 101.
See vol. 1, Introduction 7.6.1, p. 52.
In Greek – Παλμυρηνοῦ.
Found in a Jewish cemetery in Palestine, see Introduction 6.4.2.
This is the year in which Beit Sheʿarim was destroyed, see Introduction 8.4.2.3.
His son’s name and date of Pre-Christian Dura may suggest a Jew, but he appears on the wall of a Palmyrene pagan temple, see Introduction 6.8.
This is the year Dura was destroyed, see Introduction 8.4.2.2.
So in most mss to bMQ 11b, bBM 24b, bBB 8a and 12b, see Introduction 5.1.1.2.1.1. This would be the standard transliteration for this name see vol. 1, Marion (2) G/M, p. 295, n. 4.
So in Munich 95 and Vatican 134 Mss to bMQ 11b, see Introduction 5.1.1.2.1.1. The interchange of ו and י may be a scribal error, see Introduction 2.7.1.
So in the Florence II-I-9, Vatican 115 and Munich 95 Mss to bBB 26a, see Introduction 5.1.1.2.1.1. On the additional ו vowel as representing another dialect see Introduction 2.3.5.1.
Appears in rabbinic literature, and is found in association with rabbis, see Introduction 6.6.3.
Was a contemporary of Rav Ashi (2), who died in 427 CE, according to ShGa § 186, see Introduction 8.2.1.
So in most mss to bKet 105b and bBB 26a, see Introduction 5.1.1.2.1.1. This would be the standard transliteration for this name, see vol. 1, Marion (2) G/M, p. 295, n. 4.
So he appears in other mss: Vatican 115 to bBM 24b, Florence II-I-9 and Munich 95 to bBB 8a, Munich 95 to bBB 12b, see Introduction 5.1.1.2.1.1. On the additional ו see above, n. 4.
So in the Vatican 130 Ms to bKet 105b, see Introduction 5.1.1.2.1.1, and see previous note. On the additional ו and י as vowels as possibly representing another dialect see Introduction 2.3.5.1-2.
So in the Vatican 113 Ms. to bKet 105b, see Introduction 5.1.1.2.1.1. On the interchange of ר and ד as a scribal error see vol. 1, Introduction 2.7.4.
In Aramaic –מדבי בר מריון . Perhaps identical with the previous, whose house (דבי) is mentioned inbBB26a.
See above, n. 5.
Was a contemporary of Rav Joseph (5), who died in 323 CE, according to ShGa § 173, see Introduction 8.2.1.

This transliteration, with the ae cluster, represents Latin influence. The interchange of α and o is probably a scribal error, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.8.4, p. 20. On the double/single s/σ see vol. 3, Introduction 2.3.3.4, p. 16 and 2.4.3, p. 19.
This is a military list.
Jewishness may be suggested based on other name, but see Introduction 6.5.2.
This is the year Dura was destroyed, see Introduction 8.4.2.2.

In Greek – Βαβυλωναρίου. For an alternative explanation of this word, as referring to a cobbler who makes shoes Babylonian style, see M. Schwabe “A Greek Inscriptions from the Environs of Caesarea,” BIES 2 (1935) 56-7 (Hebrew).
The inscription was found in Palestine and so is likely to be Jewish, see Introduction 6.4.2.
Date suggested by the editor, see Introduction 8.4.2.3.
On this form of the name see vol. 3, Introduction 2.3.3.7.2, pp. 16-7.
The original publication is R. Mouterde/A. Poidebard, “Le Limes de Chalcis I : Texte,” Bibliothèque Archéologique et Historique 38, (Paris 1945), p. 212f., no. 47, but I have not seen it.
The inscription contains the formulaΕἵς Θεὸς̔ δύναη τὰ πάντα(one God who rules all). On such inscriptions see Introduction 6.9 .
The inscription is dated, see Introduction 8.4.1.
The inscription was found in a Jewish tomb in Jerusalem, see Introduction 6.4.1. This person is recorded in vol. 1 (Nisus [1]), p. 299, but not included in the statistics.

All the inscriptions in this tomb were identified as Palmyrene, because some of them were written in the Palmyrene script and many had Latin names, which were not typical at the time in Jerusalem, but seem to have been more so in Palmyra, see e.g. the list of Palmyrene soldiers in Welles et al. Dura-Europos (1959) 100, 101.
See vol. 1, Introduction 7.6.1, p. 52.

All the consonants of the name, as transliterated into Jewish characters, are available in this name. The additional two א are obviously vowels pointing to a different pronunciation, perhaps another dialect, see Introduction 2.5.3.3. On the transliteration of ς with ש see vol. 1, Introduction 2.2.5, pp. 20-1.
So in Isbell, BASOR 223 (1979) 16.
So in Isbell, BASOR 223 (1976) 18.
So in Isbell, BASOR 223 (1976) 16.
The scribes of the Aramaic incantation bowls were Jewish, but there is no reason to suppose that all their clients were, see Introduction 6.7.
On the dating of the Aramaic incantation bowls see Introduction 8.5.
The inscription is bilingual, Aramaic and Greek. So in the Greek. The emendations of the editor here are based on the Hebrew, see Introduction 2.1.
The inscriptions are bilingual, Aramaic and Greek. So in the Aramaic. The transliteration is straightforward, see Introduction 2.2.1.
The inscriptions are in Jewish characters, see Introduction 6.2. The persons mentioned in them are described as ̓Ιουδέων (of the Jews), see Introduction 6.1. And see also Introduction 6.4.3.
Date suggested by the editor, see Introduction 8.4.2.3.
All three versions are found in the mss of this text. On the double λ consonant see vol. 3, Introduction 2.3.3.4, p. 16. On the interchange of ι and υ see vol. 3, Introduction 2.3.3.3, p. 16.
This text is a description of a Christian-Jewish dispute.
In this religious dispute he belongs to the Jewish delegation.
The text is fictitious, and see next note.

This is a fictitious account of a religious dispute between Jews and Christians in the Sasanian court, before a fictitious Sasanian king (Arrinatus). It could have taken place in any of these centuries, see Introduction 8.1.
The inscription was found in a Jewish tomb in Jerusalem, see Introduction 6.4.1. This person is recorded in vol. 1 (Phaidon [1]), p. 309, but not included in the statistics.

All the inscriptions in this tomb were identified as Palmyrene, because some of them were written in the Palmyrene script and many had Latin names, which were not typical at the time in Jerusalem, but seem to have been more so in Palmyra, see e.g. the list of Palmyrene soldiers in Welles et al. Dura-Europos (1959) 100, 101.
See vol. 1, Introduction 7.6.1, p. 52.

div.note: Greek, WGE, 55. This is the most popular Greek name among Jews. In vol. 1 it is by far the most popular Greek name with 31 representatives (no. 13 in the general name count, see vol. 1, Table 7, p. 56), and also in vol. 3, with 62 representatives (32 of them valid Jews) it is the most popular non-biblical name (no. 8 in the general name count, see vol. 3, Table 9, p. 63). In this volume, as can be clearly seen, it is only represented once, from a Palmyrene epitaph, but ironically one found in Jerusalem. Obviously, this name had a much weaker impact on Jews in the Eastern Diaspora than it did in Palestine and the West.
WGE did not know this name, but see LGPN IIIA, 98.
Greek, WGE, 490-1. On the theophoric element in this name see vol. 3 Introduction 1.2.3.1, p. 7. On its possible Hebrew translation see vol. 1, Introduction 1.2.1, p. 11.
WGE did not know this form, but see LGPN III.B, 312.
Greek, WGE, 1363. Seleucus was a name of Hellenistic monarchs, see vol. 1, Introduction 1.2.4.2, p. 11. In this volume names of Greek monarchs are not very popular, see under Alexander G/M, n. 1.
